text: let's move on to your issue with bug
bounties how how how deep does this go
is are you you going to pound your fists
you GNA get red in the face I can yeah I
can do what you got to do tell me okay
okay so there are two core issues with
uh Bounties in open source at least how
they've been historically
executed uh so one thing is just like
bounties as a concept is great but
bounties only really work when there's
like two parties involved there's the
person setting up the Bounty who is also
the person in charge of like the quality
assurance of the deliverable and
obviously the person that you know
delivers the goods that the bount is set
up for so like a classical example is
the western movies right you set up a
bounty like capture this bad guy
$10,000 that's the US government that
says like we'll verify that you did the
right thing and then pay out
$10,000 in open source the way Bounce
has always worked is that someone just
puts up money for any issue without the
maintainers involvement awareness or
approval typically on a marketplace
where others can then like work on those
issues for that Bounty right and this
always leads to the same thing
where uh you see these GitHub issues
where this maintainer the poor
maintainer who is already suffering from
not having enough time and just getting
you know constant streams of issues
coming coming
in now he has like a lot of different
contributors coming in that are just
there for the incentive of getting the
money and if you look at those issues
it's always the same case where it's
like it's it's a race towards that cash
and so the contributions are of like
fairly low quality in comparison to like
someone being there for the right
incentives and it's a competition and a
race amongst the contributors and I
think that's the second problem which is
it's often a Marketplace approach where
it's these directories where you can
sort of sort issues by the amount that
you can
get which again just like as soon as
someone then funds it $1,000 you're
going to have like five to 10 developers
swooping in there to try to get to this
price I don't think that that is what
like open source maintainers need and
historically what we've seen is just
that they hate this and they turn it off
and so we took a very drastically
different approach which is just let's
put the maintainers in the driving seat
here and let's rather make it about how
can we fund their
efforts with the backlog and all of the
issues that we're like pouring on to
them and then give them the tools to
then distribute that funding with their
existing community of
contributors rather than setting a
Marketplace that attracts people just
for the sake of that money
[Music]
